trans-unit.source: Azure Backup - Deploy and manage back up for DPM using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup - Deploy and manage back up for DPM using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup for Data Protection Manager (DPM) using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup for Data Protection Manager (DPM) using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use PowerShell to setup Azure Backup on a DPM server, and to manage backup and recovery.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use PowerShell to setup Azure Backup on a DPM server, and to manage backup and recovery.

trans-unit.source: Before you can use PowerShell to manage backups from Data Protection Manager to Azure, you will need to have the right environment in PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use PowerShell to manage backups from Data Protection Manager to Azure, you will need to have the right environment in PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: At the start of the PowerShell session, ensure that you run the following command to import the right modules and allow you to correctly reference the DPM cmdlets:
trans-unit.target: At the start of the PowerShell session, ensure that you run the following command to import the right modules and allow you to correctly reference the DPM cmdlets:

trans-unit.source: You can create a new backup vault using the New-AzureBackupVault commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new backup vault using the New-AzureBackupVault commandlet.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the Get-AzureBackupVault commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the Get-AzureBackupVault commandlet.

trans-unit.source: Before you install the Azure Backup agent, you need to have the installer downloaded and present on the Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: Before you install the Azure Backup agent, you need to have the installer downloaded and present on the Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: You can get the latest version of the installer from the <linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title> or from the backup vault's Dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: You can get the latest version of the installer from the <linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title> or from the backup vault's Dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: Save the installer to an easily accessible location like C:\Downloads\.
trans-unit.target: Save the installer to an easily accessible location like C:\Downloads\.

trans-unit.source: To install the agent, run the following command in an elevated PowerShell console on the DPM server:
trans-unit.target: To install the agent, run the following command in an elevated PowerShell console on the DPM server:

trans-unit.source: This installs the agent with all the default options.
trans-unit.target: This installs the agent with all the default options.

trans-unit.source: The installation takes a few minutes in the background.
trans-unit.target: The installation takes a few minutes in the background.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify the /nu option the Windows Update window will open at the end of the installation to check for any updates.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify the /nu option the Windows Update window will open at the end of the installation to check for any updates.

trans-unit.source: The agent will show in the list of installed programs.
trans-unit.target: The agent will show in the list of installed programs.

trans-unit.source: To see the list of installed programs, go to Control Panel > Programs > Programs and Features.
trans-unit.target: To see the list of installed programs, go to Control Panel > Programs > Programs and Features.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Agent installed</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Agent installed</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To see all the options available via the command-line, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To see all the options available via the command-line, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: The available options include:
trans-unit.target: The available options include:

trans-unit.source: Option
trans-unit.target: Option

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: Default
trans-unit.target: Default

trans-unit.source: /q
trans-unit.target: /q

trans-unit.source: Quiet installation
trans-unit.target: Quiet installation

trans-unit.source: /p:"location"
trans-unit.target: /p:"location"

trans-unit.source: Path to the installation folder for the Azure Backup agent.
trans-unit.target: Path to the installation folder for the Azure Backup agent.

trans-unit.source: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent
trans-unit.target: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent

trans-unit.source: /s:"location"
trans-unit.target: /s:"location"

trans-unit.source: Path to the cache folder for the Azure Backup agent.
trans-unit.target: Path to the cache folder for the Azure Backup agent.

trans-unit.source: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\Scratch
trans-unit.target: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\Scratch

trans-unit.source: /m
trans-unit.target: /m

trans-unit.source: Opt-in to Microsoft Update
trans-unit.target: Opt-in to Microsoft Update

trans-unit.source: /nu
trans-unit.target: /nu

trans-unit.source: Do not Check for updates after installation is complete
trans-unit.target: Do not Check for updates after installation is complete

trans-unit.source: /d
trans-unit.target: /d

trans-unit.source: Uninstalls Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent
trans-unit.target: Uninstalls Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent

trans-unit.source: /ph
trans-unit.target: /ph

trans-unit.source: Proxy Host Address
trans-unit.target: Proxy Host Address

trans-unit.source: /po
trans-unit.target: /po

trans-unit.source: Proxy Host Port Number
trans-unit.target: Proxy Host Port Number

trans-unit.source: /pu
trans-unit.target: /pu

trans-unit.source: Proxy Host UserName
trans-unit.target: Proxy Host UserName

trans-unit.source: /pw
trans-unit.target: /pw

trans-unit.source: Proxy Password
trans-unit.target: Proxy Password

trans-unit.source: Before you can register with the Azure Backup service, you need to ensure that the <linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title> are met.
trans-unit.target: Before you can register with the Azure Backup service, you need to ensure that the <linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title> are met.

trans-unit.source: You must:
trans-unit.target: You must:

trans-unit.source: Have a valid Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Have a valid Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Have a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Have a backup vault

trans-unit.source: To download the vault credentials, run the Get-AzureBackupVaultCredentials commandlet in an Azure PowerShell console and store it in a convenient location like C:\Downloads\.
trans-unit.target: To download the vault credentials, run the Get-AzureBackupVaultCredentials commandlet in an Azure PowerShell console and store it in a convenient location like C:\Downloads\.

trans-unit.source: Registering the machine with the vault is done using the <linkText>Start-DPMCloudRegistration</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Registering the machine with the vault is done using the <linkText>Start-DPMCloudRegistration</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: This will register the DPM Server named “TestingServer” with Microsoft Azure Vault using the specified vault credentials.
trans-unit.target: This will register the DPM Server named “TestingServer” with Microsoft Azure Vault using the specified vault credentials.

trans-unit.source: Do not use relative paths to specify the vault credentials file.
trans-unit.target: Do not use relative paths to specify the vault credentials file.

trans-unit.source: You must provide an absolute path as an input to the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You must provide an absolute path as an input to the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Once the DPM Server is registered with the Azure Backup vault, it will start with default subscription settings.
trans-unit.target: Once the DPM Server is registered with the Azure Backup vault, it will start with default subscription settings.

trans-unit.source: These subscription settings include Networking, Encryption and the Staging area.
trans-unit.target: These subscription settings include Networking, Encryption and the Staging area.

trans-unit.source: To begin changing the subscription settings you need to first get a handle on the existing (default) settings using the <linkText>Get-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To begin changing the subscription settings you need to first get a handle on the existing (default) settings using the <linkText>Get-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: All modifications are made to this local PowerShell object $setting and then the full object is committed to DPM and Azure Backup to save them using the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: All modifications are made to this local PowerShell object $setting and then the full object is committed to DPM and Azure Backup to save them using the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You need to use the –Commit flag to ensure that the changes are persisted.
trans-unit.target: You need to use the –Commit flag to ensure that the changes are persisted.

trans-unit.source: The settings will not be applied and used by Azure Backup unless committed.
trans-unit.target: The settings will not be applied and used by Azure Backup unless committed.

trans-unit.source: If the connectivity of the DPM machine to the Azure Backup service on the internet is through a proxy server, then the proxy server settings should be provided for backups to succeed.
trans-unit.target: If the connectivity of the DPM machine to the Azure Backup service on the internet is through a proxy server, then the proxy server settings should be provided for backups to succeed.

trans-unit.source: This is done by using the -ProxyServer, -ProxyPort, -ProxyUsername and the ProxyPassword parameters with the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: This is done by using the -ProxyServer, -ProxyPort, -ProxyUsername and the ProxyPassword parameters with the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In this example, there is no proxy server so we are explicitly clearing any proxy-related information.
trans-unit.target: In this example, there is no proxy server so we are explicitly clearing any proxy-related information.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth usage can also be controlled with options of -WorkHourBandwidth and -NonWorkHourBandwidth for a given set of days of the week.
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth usage can also be controlled with options of -WorkHourBandwidth and -NonWorkHourBandwidth for a given set of days of the week.

trans-unit.source: In this example we are not setting any throttling.
trans-unit.target: In this example we are not setting any throttling.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Backup agent running on the DPM server needs temporary storage for data restored from the cloud (local staging area).
trans-unit.target: The Azure Backup agent running on the DPM server needs temporary storage for data restored from the cloud (local staging area).

trans-unit.source: Configure the staging area using the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet and the -StagingAreaPath parameter.
trans-unit.target: Configure the staging area using the Set-DPMCloudSubscriptionSetting cmdlet and the -StagingAreaPath parameter.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, the staging area will be set to C:\StagingArea in the PowerShell object $setting.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, the staging area will be set to C:\StagingArea in the PowerShell object $setting.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the specified folder already exists, or else the final commit of the subscription settings will fail.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the specified folder already exists, or else the final commit of the subscription settings will fail.

trans-unit.source: The backup data sent to Azure Backup is encrypted to protect the confidentiality of the data.
trans-unit.target: The backup data sent to Azure Backup is encrypted to protect the confidentiality of the data.

trans-unit.source: The encryption passphrase is the "password" to decrypt the data at the time of restore.
trans-unit.target: The encryption passphrase is the "password" to decrypt the data at the time of restore.

trans-unit.source: It is important to keep this information safe and secure once it is set.
trans-unit.target: It is important to keep this information safe and secure once it is set.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the first command converts the string passphrase123456789 to a secure string and assigns the secure string to the variable named $Passphrase.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the first command converts the string passphrase123456789 to a secure string and assigns the secure string to the variable named $Passphrase.

trans-unit.source: the second command sets the secure string in $Passphrase as the password for encrypting backups.
trans-unit.target: the second command sets the secure string in $Passphrase as the password for encrypting backups.

trans-unit.source: Keep the passphrase information safe and secure once it is set.
trans-unit.target: Keep the passphrase information safe and secure once it is set.

trans-unit.source: You will not be able to restore data from Azure without this passphrase.
trans-unit.target: You will not be able to restore data from Azure without this passphrase.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you should have made all the required changes to the $setting object.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you should have made all the required changes to the $setting object.

trans-unit.source: Remember to commit the changes.
trans-unit.target: Remember to commit the changes.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will add a production server to DPM and then protect the data to local DPM storage and then to Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will add a production server to DPM and then protect the data to local DPM storage and then to Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: In the examples we will demonstrate how to back up files and folders.
trans-unit.target: In the examples we will demonstrate how to back up files and folders.

trans-unit.source: The logic can easily be extended to backup any DPM-supported data source.
trans-unit.target: The logic can easily be extended to backup any DPM-supported data source.

trans-unit.source: All your DPM backups are governed by a Protection Group (PG) with four parts:
trans-unit.target: All your DPM backups are governed by a Protection Group (PG) with four parts:

trans-unit.source: Group members is a list of all the protectable objects (also known as Datasources in DPM) that you want to protect in the same protection group.
trans-unit.target: Group members is a list of all the protectable objects (also known as Datasources in DPM) that you want to protect in the same protection group.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may want to protect production VMs in one protection group and SQL Server databases in another protection group as they may have different backup requirements.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may want to protect production VMs in one protection group and SQL Server databases in another protection group as they may have different backup requirements.

trans-unit.source: Before you can back up any datasource on a production server you need to make sure the DPM Agent is installed on the server and is managed by DPM.
trans-unit.target: Before you can back up any datasource on a production server you need to make sure the DPM Agent is installed on the server and is managed by DPM.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps for <linkText>installing the DPM Agent</linkText><title></title> and linking it to the appropriate DPM Server.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps for <linkText>installing the DPM Agent</linkText><title></title> and linking it to the appropriate DPM Server.

trans-unit.source: Data protection method specifies the target backup locations - tape, disk, and cloud.
trans-unit.target: Data protection method specifies the target backup locations - tape, disk, and cloud.

trans-unit.source: In our example we will protect data to the local disk and to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: In our example we will protect data to the local disk and to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A backup schedule that specifies when backups need to be taken and how often the data should be synchronized between the DPM Server and the production server.
trans-unit.target: A backup schedule that specifies when backups need to be taken and how often the data should be synchronized between the DPM Server and the production server.

trans-unit.source: A retention schedule that specifies how long to retain the recovery points in Azure.
trans-unit.target: A retention schedule that specifies how long to retain the recovery points in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a new Protection Group using the <linkText>New-DPMProtectionGroup</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a new Protection Group using the <linkText>New-DPMProtectionGroup</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The above cmdlet will create a Protection Group named ProtectGroup01.
trans-unit.target: The above cmdlet will create a Protection Group named ProtectGroup01.

trans-unit.source: An existing protection group can also be modified later to add backup to the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: An existing protection group can also be modified later to add backup to the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: However, to make any changes to the Protection Group - new or existing - we need to get a handle on a modifiable object using the Get-DPMModifiableProtectionGroup cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: However, to make any changes to the Protection Group - new or existing - we need to get a handle on a modifiable object using the Get-DPMModifiableProtectionGroup cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Each DPM Agent knows the list of datasources on the server that it is installed on.
trans-unit.target: Each DPM Agent knows the list of datasources on the server that it is installed on.

trans-unit.source: To add a datasource to the Protection Group, the DPM Agent needs to first send a list of the datasources back to the DPM server.
trans-unit.target: To add a datasource to the Protection Group, the DPM Agent needs to first send a list of the datasources back to the DPM server.

trans-unit.source: One or more datasources are then selected and added to the Protection Group.
trans-unit.target: One or more datasources are then selected and added to the Protection Group.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell steps needed to get achieve this are:
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell steps needed to get achieve this are:

trans-unit.source: Fetch a list of all servers managed by DPM through the DPM Agent.
trans-unit.target: Fetch a list of all servers managed by DPM through the DPM Agent.

trans-unit.source: Choose a specific server.
trans-unit.target: Choose a specific server.

trans-unit.source: Fetch a list of all datasources on the server.
trans-unit.target: Fetch a list of all datasources on the server.

trans-unit.source: Choose one or more datasources and add them to the Protection Group
trans-unit.target: Choose one or more datasources and add them to the Protection Group

trans-unit.source: The list of servers on which the DPM Agent is installed and is being managed by the DPM Server is acquired with the <linkText>Get-DPMProductionServer</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The list of servers on which the DPM Agent is installed and is being managed by the DPM Server is acquired with the <linkText>Get-DPMProductionServer</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In this example we will filter and only configure PS with name productionserver01 for backup.
trans-unit.target: In this example we will filter and only configure PS with name productionserver01 for backup.

trans-unit.source: Now fetch the list of datasources on $server using the Get-DPMDatasource cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Now fetch the list of datasources on $server using the Get-DPMDatasource cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In this example we are filtering for the volume D:\ which we want to configure for backup.
trans-unit.target: In this example we are filtering for the volume D:\ which we want to configure for backup.

trans-unit.source: This datasource is then added to the Protection Group using the <linkText>Add-DPMChildDatasource</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: This datasource is then added to the Protection Group using the <linkText>Add-DPMChildDatasource</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Remember to use the modifable protection group object $MPG to make the additions.
trans-unit.target: Remember to use the modifable protection group object $MPG to make the additions.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this step as many times as required, until you have added all the chosen datasources to the protection group.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this step as many times as required, until you have added all the chosen datasources to the protection group.

trans-unit.source: You can also start with just one datasource, and complete the workflow for creating the Protection Group, and at a later point add more datasources to the Protection Group.
trans-unit.target: You can also start with just one datasource, and complete the workflow for creating the Protection Group, and at a later point add more datasources to the Protection Group.

trans-unit.source: Once the datasources have been added to the Protection Group, the next step is to specify the protection method using the <linkText>Set-DPMProtectionType</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Once the datasources have been added to the Protection Group, the next step is to specify the protection method using the <linkText>Set-DPMProtectionType</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the Protection Group will be setup for local disk and cloud backup.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the Protection Group will be setup for local disk and cloud backup.

trans-unit.source: Set the retention for the backup points using the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicyObjective</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Set the retention for the backup points using the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicyObjective</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: While it might seem odd to set the retention before the backup schedule has been defined, using the Set-DPMPolicyObjective cmdlet automatically sets a default backup schedule that can then be modified.
trans-unit.target: While it might seem odd to set the retention before the backup schedule has been defined, using the Set-DPMPolicyObjective cmdlet automatically sets a default backup schedule that can then be modified.

trans-unit.source: It is always possible to set the backup schedule first and the retention policy after.
trans-unit.target: It is always possible to set the backup schedule first and the retention policy after.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the cmdlet sets the retention parameters for disk backups.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the cmdlet sets the retention parameters for disk backups.

trans-unit.source: This will retain backups for 10 days, and sync data every 6 hours between the production server and the DPM server.
trans-unit.target: This will retain backups for 10 days, and sync data every 6 hours between the production server and the DPM server.

trans-unit.source: The SynchronizationFrequencyMinutes doesn't define how often a backup point is created, but how often data is copied to the DPM server; this prevents backups from becoming too large.
trans-unit.target: The SynchronizationFrequencyMinutes doesn't define how often a backup point is created, but how often data is copied to the DPM server; this prevents backups from becoming too large.

trans-unit.source: For backups going to Azure (DPM refers to these as Online backups) the retention ranges can be configured for <linkText>long term retention using a Grandfather-Father-Son scheme (GFS)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For backups going to Azure (DPM refers to these as Online backups) the retention ranges can be configured for <linkText>long term retention using a Grandfather-Father-Son scheme (GFS)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: That is, you can define a combined retention policy involving daily, weekly, monthly and yearly retention policies.
trans-unit.target: That is, you can define a combined retention policy involving daily, weekly, monthly and yearly retention policies.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we create an array representing the complex retention scheme that we want, and then configure the retention range using the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicyObjective</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we create an array representing the complex retention scheme that we want, and then configure the retention range using the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicyObjective</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: DPM sets a default backup schedule automatically if you specify the protection objective using the Set-DPMPolicyObjective cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: DPM sets a default backup schedule automatically if you specify the protection objective using the Set-DPMPolicyObjective cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: To change the default schedules, use the <linkText>Get-DPMPolicySchedule</linkText><title></title> cmdlet followed by the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicySchedule</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To change the default schedules, use the <linkText>Get-DPMPolicySchedule</linkText><title></title> cmdlet followed by the <linkText>Set-DPMPolicySchedule</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, $onlineSch is an array with four elements that contains the existing online protection schedule for the Protection Group in the GFS scheme:
trans-unit.target: In the example above, $onlineSch is an array with four elements that contains the existing online protection schedule for the Protection Group in the GFS scheme:

trans-unit.source: $onlineSch[0] will contain the daily schedule
trans-unit.target: $onlineSch[0] will contain the daily schedule

trans-unit.source: $onlineSch[1] will contain the weekly schedule
trans-unit.target: $onlineSch[1] will contain the weekly schedule

trans-unit.source: $onlineSch[2] will contain the monthly schedule
trans-unit.target: $onlineSch[2] will contain the monthly schedule

trans-unit.source: $onlineSch[3] will contain the yearly schedule
trans-unit.target: $onlineSch[3] will contain the yearly schedule

trans-unit.source: So if you need to modify the weekly schedule, you need to refer to the $onlineSch[1].
trans-unit.target: So if you need to modify the weekly schedule, you need to refer to the $onlineSch[1].

trans-unit.source: When backing up a datasource for the first time, DPM needs to create an initial replica which will create a copy of the datasource to be protected on DPM replica volume.
trans-unit.target: When backing up a datasource for the first time, DPM needs to create an initial replica which will create a copy of the datasource to be protected on DPM replica volume.

trans-unit.source: This activity can either be scheduled for a specific time, or can be triggered manually, using the Set-DPMReplicaCreationMethod cmdlet with the parameter -NOW.
trans-unit.target: This activity can either be scheduled for a specific time, or can be triggered manually, using the Set-DPMReplicaCreationMethod cmdlet with the parameter -NOW.

trans-unit.source: You can also change the size of DPM Replica volume as well as Shadow Copy volume using [Set-DPMDatasourceDiskAllocation](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh881618(v=sc.20).aspx) cmdlet as in the below example: Get-DatasourceDiskAllocation -Datasource $DS Set-DatasourceDiskAllocation -Datasource $DS -ProtectionGroup $MPG -manual -ReplicaArea (2gb) -ShadowCopyArea (2gb)
trans-unit.target: You can also change the size of DPM Replica volume as well as Shadow Copy volume using [Set-DPMDatasourceDiskAllocation](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh881618(v=sc.20).aspx) cmdlet as in the below example: Get-DatasourceDiskAllocation -Datasource $DS Set-DatasourceDiskAllocation -Datasource $DS -ProtectionGroup $MPG -manual -ReplicaArea (2gb) -ShadowCopyArea (2gb)

trans-unit.source: Finally, the changes need to be committed before DPM can take the backup per the new Protection Group configuration.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the changes need to be committed before DPM can take the backup per the new Protection Group configuration.

trans-unit.source: This is done using the <linkText>Set-DPMProtectionGroup</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: This is done using the <linkText>Set-DPMProtectionGroup</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can use the <linkText>Get-DPMRecoveryPoint</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to get a list of all recovery points for a datasource.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <linkText>Get-DPMRecoveryPoint</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to get a list of all recovery points for a datasource.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will:
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will:

trans-unit.source: fetch all the PGs on the DPM server which will be stored in an array $PG
trans-unit.target: fetch all the PGs on the DPM server which will be stored in an array $PG

trans-unit.source: get the datasources corresponding to the $PG[0]
trans-unit.target: get the datasources corresponding to the $PG[0]

trans-unit.source: get all the recovery points for a datasource.
trans-unit.target: get all the recovery points for a datasource.

trans-unit.source: Restoring data is a combination of a RecoverableItem object and a RecoveryOption object.
trans-unit.target: Restoring data is a combination of a RecoverableItem object and a RecoveryOption object.

trans-unit.source: In the previous section, we got a list of the backup points for a datasource.
trans-unit.target: In the previous section, we got a list of the backup points for a datasource.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, we demonstrate how to restore a Hyper-V virtual machine from Azure Backup by combining backup points with the target for recovery.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, we demonstrate how to restore a Hyper-V virtual machine from Azure Backup by combining backup points with the target for recovery.

trans-unit.source: This includes:
trans-unit.target: This includes:

trans-unit.source: Creating a recovery option using the <linkText>New-DPMRecoveryOption</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Creating a recovery option using the <linkText>New-DPMRecoveryOption</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
